patches.reasoning: These prior knowledge points ensure that pupils have a basic understanding of the Roman Empire and its influence on Britain.

value: The Roman Empire was a powerful civilisation that controlled large parts of Europe.
Britain was part of the Roman Empire for several hundred years.
Romans built roads, forts, and towns in Britain.
Roman soldiers were stationed in Britain to maintain control.
Anglo-Saxons were groups from Europe who began to settle in Britain after the Romans.

patches.reasoning: These key learning points highlight the major aspects of the topic, ensuring pupils grasp the essential historical changes.

value: Roman Britain ended around 410 AD when the Romans left.
The Roman army withdrew from Britain to defend other parts of the Empire.
Life changed in Britain as Roman structures and systems were abandoned.
The Anglo-Saxons began to establish control in parts of Britain.

patches.reasoning: These misconceptions address common misunderstandings about the continuity of Roman influence and the nature of the transition to Anglo-Saxon rule.

value.description: Many believe the Romans left abruptly, but it was a gradual process over years. This can be clarified by explaining the gradual withdrawal of troops and resources.

value.misconception: All aspects of Roman life disappeared after 410 AD
value.description: Some Roman influences remained, such as roads. This can be addressed by discussing which Roman legacies continued.

value.definition: An extensive group of states or countries ruled over by a single monarch or ruling authority.
The period when the Roman Empire controlled Britain, lasting from 43 to about 410 AD.
Groups from Europe who settled in Britain after the Romans left around 410 AD.
